title: "like new"
content: Bought this as it was labeled "like new", and was my only option for getting a switch. Upon delivery, one joycon controller was broken ( no peg to lock it in and not even holding a charge) the screen is also scratched, as well the back of it, and it's missing the controller attachment for the joycons. It's like it wasn't even checked before it was sent. Tldr; switch came with a completely broken joycon, scratches on screen and back(not a super huge deal, just annoyed because the lable of like new), and it's missing the controller for the joycons. Edit: changed to 4 stars. Fast reply and a refund which is enough to replace the missing/damaged  items.
variant: Style: Console Color: Gray
author: Jake Hawfield
product: Nintendo Switch with Gray Joy‑Con - HAC-001(-01)
Split_1: Bought this as it was labeled "like new", and was my only option for getting a switch.

Split_4: Tldr; switch came with a completely broken joycon, scratches on screen and back(not a super huge deal, just annoyed because the lable of like new), and it's missing the controller for the joycons.

title: Definite buy IMHO, but its made for tiny hands. Buy larger controllers separately.
content: Such a good console.  Bought it so I can play games with my family. We Play super smash bros, animal crossing,  mario kart. I like that you don't need to buy extra remotes to play with someone else.  The console is loaded with a bunch of cool features like the ability to switch play from handheld to TV mode instantly. In my opinion,  it is a definite buy if you are interested. My kids love it and so do I. My only issue which is not really an issue is that my hands cramp when I play because the "Joy con" remotes  that come with the console are made for the tiny little hands of children (and not those of an adult). Nintendo is aware of this though and have made  larger controllers available for purchase separately that easily sync to the console.
variant: Style: Console Color: Mario Red & Blue Edition
author: Alejandro castillo
product: Nintendo Switch with Gray Joy‑Con - HAC-001(-01)

title: Situation Better than You May Think
content: First of all, I wanna say that although Amazon may have some date when they say it will be in stock or some date when they say it’ll be delivered, just know that it may be earlier than anticipated. I ordered mine thinking it wasn’t gonna be here until  around June 4th, so about 3 weeks to a month after I ordered the switch, but fortunately, it came 2 weeks earlier! Apparently, I’m far from the only one who has experienced this, and a number of people have gotten their switch earlier than expected, so don’t look at the date thinking that’s when you’re gonna get it, ‘cause you may just get a nice surprise like a number of customers did. Yes, there are some stock issues with the switch at the moment as well as some production issues, but they are not as bad as they’re made out to be, so if you are thinking about getting the switch, go ahead and pull the trigger! Also, DO NOT BUY FRON SCALPERS. As some other people have mentioned, they will buy a switch and then sell it for a greater price than needed in order to make a profit, and although it may be tempting to buy from them so you can get it sooner, it is so not worth paying the extra money when the situation is actually better than amazon makes it out to be. Don’t do yourself a disservice and fall into the instant gratification trap. Be willing to wait a little bit longer for your switch. YOU’LL BE GLAD YOU DID.

title: Nintendo's Faulty Hardware.
content: This is a bit of a rant of a review, but I think it's necessary. Nintendo pushed out a product that revolutionized the gaming industry, but they did it in all the wrong ways. So much faulty hardware it's ridiculous. Shortly after purchasing you'll realize your joycons are broken, drifting to the side which ruins the gaming experience. (I've gone through 3, yes, THREE pairs of $80 joycons.) And they will disconnect from the console as a whole which sucks as well especially if you're on an online game or a combat orientated game like BOTW and Splatoon. Leaving you a sitting duck ready to lose because you have to wait for your joycons to reconnect. Also, there is such an issue with the joycons as a whole there have been class action lawsuits against Nintendo because of them. My joycons don't even connect for handheld play anymore so my switch has become a stationary console, and then next to obliterate any chances of me enjoying my switch, that cost just as much as my quality controlled systems like my Xbox, the fan completely quit working which has reduced this console to a ticking time bomb of how long I can actually enjoy it before it auto shuts off unless I fork up the $80 to get it repaired. Which I find ridiculous seeing as I've had all these issues and my switch isn't even a year old.
variant: Style: Console Color: Neon Blue and Red
author: Naomi
product: Nintendo Switch with Gray Joy‑Con - HAC-001(-01)
Split_1: This is a bit of a rant of a review, but I think it's necessary.
Split_2: Nintendo pushed out a product that revolutionized the gaming industry, but they did it in all the wrong ways.
Split_3: So much faulty hardware it's ridiculous.
Split_4: Shortly after purchasing you'll realize your joycons are broken, drifting to the side which ruins the gaming experience.

title: Might Not Be Brand New As Advertised
content: I received my switch a lot sooner than expected, and I bought a new one but I'm not so sure that it's actually brand new. I had watched a couple of unboxing videos beforehand and it was supposed to come with the standard 32GB memory card, but it didn't; the slot was empty and the flap on the box to open it looks like it has been opened before, which leads me to believe that Amazon might not actually be selling brand new switches. Aside from that, everything looks really good with no scratches and works great so far. I'll give an update if anything changes.

title: Worth it if you want it
content: The ability to swap from dock to handheld still amazes me to this day. The library of games is crazy good, The battery life isn't bad, and the build is fairly durable. The screen is prone to scratching due to it being plastic, but a $10 screen protector fixes that easily. The controllers do go bad over time. I would recommend also purchasing a pro controller due to it having a better feel for me personally and they last far longer than any Joycon I've had. This purchase date was for my sister but I've had mine since near release and have gone through 3 pairs of Joycon, meanwhile my oldest pro controller (between 4 or 5 years) of the 3 I currently have has only shown slight signs of degradation. There is a "Nintendo tax" on some games which basically means they cost more than they would on other consoles (e.g. Borderlands collection I got on pc for like $20 where as the switch is charging $50 for games released between 2009-2014 so that you can play them on graphically worse hardware, but the portable part may be worth it for some people with certain games). The online services are really bad a lot of the time especially when playing with people who are far away or have otherwise unstable connections. Playing with random people online can be a very painstaking process a lot of the time. With all this being said, I love this console. It is the only console I use (I also have a pc and a ps4). I only look at it so critically due to how much I love it. If I didn't spend hours and hours using this thing I wouldn't be telling you all it's flaws in a 4-star review. It can be frustrating sometimes, but the exclusives are amazing (there are also a lot of great 3rd party games but I mainly mean that BOTW is a masterpiece and Mario Odyssey is phenomenal) and the "home console and handheld" idea is honestly incredible. I basically wrote an essay about this thing to tell you how much I love it.
variant: Style: Console Color: Neon Blue and Red
author: Elijah Maciejewski
product: Nintendo Switch with Gray Joy‑Con - HAC-001(-01)
Split_1: The ability to swap from dock to handheld still amazes me to this day.
Split_2: The library of games is crazy good, The battery life isn't bad, and the build is fairly durable.
Split_3: The screen is prone to scratching due to it being plastic, but a $10 screen protector fixes that easily.
Split_4: The controllers do go bad over time.

title: This switch is phenomenal well worth the price
content: The Mario red and blue edition Nintendo switch was released to celebrate a game launch, which was super Mario 3d world, and it also was released to celebrate the 35rh anniversary of Super Mario Bros. It came with a carrying case which reflects the red and blue of the console, a screen protector, a dock that matches the switch, joy con straps that are blue, with a nice red blue and gold braided strap, the plastic piece that tightens the strap is a nice yellow, and a blue joy con grip. It doesn't include Super Mario 3D World, but the case and screen protector really makes it worth it. The con is the rails are still black and the kickstand isn't red or blue, but the black looks nice in contrast. This console is the HAC-001-01 model, so it has improved battery life. Don't support scalpers unless you feel like you have to, but they're at least not charging as much as the Animal Crossing New Horizons edition.

title: Tons of games to choose from
content: Great system.  My son owns one but has it with him at college so I decided to get one for myself and I must say it's got such a huge selection of games.  I still have my 3ds but didn't realize how much Nintendo had expanded on game selection and variety. I'm a huge animal crossing fan so I bought this version of Switch since I played the first one on the 3ds.  Their online eshop, accessible through an online connection, has an almost endless selection of games.  You can buy physical copies or digital copies of games and some are digital only through the eshop.  As a longtime gamer (I own a PS4 and original owner of a regular NES I bought in 1989), I can honestly say this is Nintendo's best system since you can play it on your TV but also take it with you (portable) like a 3ds.  You can also play games on it offline so you don't have to always be connected to the internet.  This is a console that is great for all ages of people, young or old and when I'm tired of hack and slash on my PS4, the Switch has many chill titles of games to relax with.  I'm 52 and enjoy my Switch a lot.
variant: Style: Console Color: Green and Blue
author: Susanna Medrano
product: Nintendo Switch with Gray Joy‑Con - HAC-001(-01)
Split_1: Great system.
Split_2: My son owns one but has it with him at college so I decided to get one for myself and I must say it's got such a huge selection of games.
Split_3: I still have my 3ds but didn't realize how much Nintendo had expanded on game selection and variety.
Split_4: I'm a huge animal crossing fan so I bought this version of Switch since I played the first one on the 3ds.

title: The Nintendo Switch is great for family use
content: The switch is a awesome gaming console, I use it for the family, here is some of the games I play with the family and maybe some of you guys can incorporate to add family time to play these games with. - Mario Party - Mario Kart - Just Dance - Monopoly - Uno - Carnival - Family Fued - Jack in the Box I recommend the switch because it's overall and handy console you can go anywhere with and play games. You can even take it on vacation and play it too. I believe this is worth the $300 you pay for it. Just letting you know by playing some of these games you may burn friendships with you family members since they will probably be salty you beat them in something!

title: Works Like A Charm, Glad I Pre-Ordered
content: Around the time everyone got their money, I had been searching for a Nintendo Switch. Me and someone else chipped in and started lurking the net. We searched everywhere! Target, Walmart, BestBuy, and even GameStop. No body had any Nintendo Switches in and some people was jacking the prices even higher as they was a bulk buyer. We had been heart broken, we was unsure when they would ever update or even announce the next re-stock. Fortunately for us, Amazon had allowed you to be able to pre-order the next stock. So I did. The shipment came faster then expected and cheaper then any store really had sold it for. The package was lovely, just as pictured, and nothing was scratched or broken. Nor was anything of the sort missing, all had been given. The Switch itself runs perfectly and the gameplay is very high quality. The buttons and sticks do not get stuck and are easy to press on. Everything is easy to use and to navigate as a newbie. I would highly recommend this product. ^^

title: Too many mistakes?🤦
content: Just like the title shows this console has lot of mistakes. First mistake is the charging when you go to charge it that it'll automatically turn on which will ware it down more sooner if not shut down after being plugged in. Second mistake is not able to be put it into airplane mode while operating in TV mode until you put it into handheld mode which makes no sense because it shuts down both the wireless controllers and Amiibo instead of having options to shut off the online function without disconnected everything else at the same time when feeling playing offline in TV mode. Third mistake is the charging dock and this one got me confused because in the front part where screen goes is solid plastic which will scratch the screen which I was aware of from watching YouTube videos and I was smart enough to get a screen protector but yet think that Nintendo would put in some type of foam or padding for that reason by now. If it didn't have any decent games I wouldn't bought it where I'm giving it 3 star review for the games that work on it.

title: I'm almost 40 years old and I bought a switch?
content: Let's face it. If you're an old millennial like myself then there's a huge chance you've grown up with nintendo in your life. I got an nes for Christmas when I was 5 years old  (that was in 1986...d@mn i feel old) and it was the best thing ever. After contemplating the switch and putting it off for years, I finally bought one (mario edition cause red is cool). Is it the best console? Especially for an adult with no kids? Probably not. Microsoft and Sony are far superior systems as far as hardware and software goes. But is it the best console for nostalgia and simple yet addictive gaming that is guaranteed to make you flashback to a time when life was so much simpler? Absolutely. The fact that I can play at home or effortlessly take it with me is a major selling point. The other being a classic series of games (and the modern versions of them) that we grew up with. Zero buyers remorse. So whether you're from the nintendo generation like myself or you have kids (or no kids) I say if you've been thinking about buying a switch then just get one. I pretty much guarantee you'll love it.
variant: Style: Console Color: Mario Red & Blue Edition
author: Keith, Tam and Dar
product: Nintendo Switch with Gray Joy‑Con - HAC-001(-01)
Split_1: Let's face it.
Split_2: If you're an old millennial like myself then there's a huge chance you've grown up with nintendo in your life.
Split_3: I got an nes for Christmas when I was 5 years old  (that was in 1986...d@mn i feel old) and it was the best thing ever.
Split_4: After contemplating the switch and putting it off for years, I finally bought one (mario edition cause red is cool).

title: Love the Switch! Great Versatility and a Great Game Catalog!
content: I really wasn’t sure if I wanted to get a Nintendo Switch. But now I love the Switch! I’m just getting into it in 2021. I was first a PC player and then just a Playstation player. I love the Switch’s versatility going from handheld to docked mode. I play mine mainly docked on my 4k monitor. The stock joycons aren’t that comfortable so I bought the Hori Split Pad controllers, and I use a Pro controller while docked. There’s also the joycon drift issue but I haven’t experienced that. The first party games on the Switch are unique from Playstation and Xbox. They give you game experiences that are unique to Nintendo. There are also good 3rd party games that have been brought to the Switch. Overall I’ve been very impressed with the Switch and it’s been the only console I’ve played for the last 3-4 months. We’ll just have to see if Nintendo brings on a revised Switch in the next year or so. I highly recommend the Switch!

As I was looking I was so lucky to see the animal crossing special edition back in stock and not at a scalping price. But at the normal price of 299.99, but when the first package was delivered it got stolen because Amazon delivery didn't know, customer service at first had an aditude with me. I had assume they didn't believe me that it was stolen. But it was and at the end of the day. Im so grateful they were able to replace the console with out Me having to get my money back because I saw that the price instantly jump from 299.99 to 360.00 which I would never recomend buying it at that price.

title: BUY AT YOUR OWN RISK!!!
content: I bought this for my son for Christmas... two weeks later it simply stopped taking charge with no apparent damage to the charging port. Sent it to Nintendo for repair, they sent it back unrepaired and said it was not covered by the warranty. I recently sent it again and was charged by Nintendo $115 for repair. My issue here is that Amazon is selling defective products, Nintendo does not want to fix their products nor did they reach out to me to ask if I want to pay for the repair. It costs more than $300, who in their right mind would throw it away. Now to repair I paid more than $100 so I'm close to $500 for a damn Switch! I could of just bought a PS5 with that money.

title: Absolute Trash!
content: CONS! 1. They say you get a FREE 7 DAY TRIAL MEMBERSHIP. This is a complete scam. When you try to sign up it asks you to pick a membership which you assume starts AFTER the free trial! Nope you get charged instantly, and you get no trial! Classic bait and switch. 2. Joy Con Drift! After a few months your controllers will drift all over on their own. Class action lawsuit already underway for this. 3. SLOW! It took 45 minutes to download Rocket League on this thing. I have a super fast connection and would take only a couple minutes on a laptop. 4. Bad Controls! I played Mario 35 (which I can only play for 2 days before they delete it off my device! WTF!) And having played thousands of hours on Mario on previous gen consoles this one has the button locations set in very weird spots. (I can probably remap the buttons, but why are they so unconventional for the defaults. 5. It's EXPENSIVE! Nintendo has for years created artificial shortages of their products to create hype which then creates strong sales for them, so they constantly do this in waves which means when in stock the "flippers" stock up on them and gouge you on prices when Nintendo does their fake shortage thing. 6. It's OLD! This console had specs when new 5 or 6 years ago. The graphics are horrible when compared to the new Playstation and Xbox. 7. Nintendo hates it's customers. Nintendo has sued people for streaming and posting video gameplay. And for years charged YouTubers to show their content. Talk about greed! PROS 1. Good resale value
variant: Style: Console Color: Green and Blue
author: ThumpersMilk
product: Nintendo Switch with Gray Joy‑Con - HAC-001(-01)
Split_1: CONS!
Split_3: They say you get a FREE 7 DAY TRIAL MEMBERSHIP.

title: The best gaming console!!
content: I cannot rave about the Switch enough!!! It truly is one of the best gaming consoles. I never was really a big “gamer” but always enjoyed Nintendo games such as Mario Kart and other related games. This console is great for both kids and adults, it is also great for solo or multiplayer games. I absolutely love the convenience of being able to play either on the big screen or handheld mode. The battery life on the handheld is pretty good for it being a larger sized console but if you’re playing for multiple hours I will need to be charged. All in all this truly was one of the best purchases I’ve made for entertainment. I highly recommend this console to everyone of all ages!

title: The cutest!
content: Needless to say, the Nintendo Switch is so much fun and a great way to kill time.  But on top of that, this particular console's Animal Crossing theme is just the cutest I've ever seen.  I never liked the primary-looking colors of the OG console, so the soft blue and mint green joy con colors really appealed to me.  The back of the switch itself has rivers and islands etched onto it as well!  It's the little details that really make a difference for me.  The dock is a light cream color with the raccoon travel agents on the bottom right.  I'm so glad this set was available again because, although I'm sure I'd be happy with the OG console, I'm so much happier with my Animal Crossing edition.  It makes me smile every time I see it.  I've never even played the game before I bought it, but it ended up being my first game purchase and it makes me even more happy that I bought this edition.  I love it!

I’ve replaced the power cord hoping that was why it wouldn’t charge.  Tried charging it on the cradle as well as directly plugged into the charging cord.  No success with either.  The unit will not power on.

title: Worth the money wait and hunt.
content: Ok. The Switch is a masterpiece when it comes to the library. I’ve spent more time than I would like to admit playing Breath of the Wild. Smash Ultimate is the best in the series, along with Mario maker 2. The resolution is a problem for some other hardcore gamers, but HD is fine for me. I really don’t care if it’s not “4K, 60fps”. The controls are super advanced. Li always play with the grip, even if Motion controls are recommended. I don’t personally own a Pro controller for the switch, but I’ll consider it. I have a Wii U Pro-controller which is my favorite controller for the system. The Switch approves upon the Wii U in most ways. The Wii U does however possess a better UI, more comfortable controls, and Virtual console. Overall the Nintendo Switch is worth the hunt and the money. The console has the best library since the N64.
variant: Style: Console Color: Neon Blue and Red
author: Owen L.
product: Nintendo Switch with Gray Joy‑Con - HAC-001(-01)

title: Family Fun System With Issues
content: The switch is a fun system when it works. 3 months in this piece of delicate plastic stopped "switching." The console works when plugged into the dock and displays on the TV but not when removed from the dock. When removed from the dock the screen is black but sound can be heard. A hard reset reveals the Nintendo logo for a split second then the switch image for a split second, by accident. Then blackness. Placing the console back on the dock allows you to play on the TV but what is the point if the handheld device does not work. Contacted Nintendo support and after some time-wasting, I'll need to send it in for a warranty repair. Should be without the device for over a month by current estimates. Another issue: Setting up the 37 accounts, email logins, user names, and other associated nicknames and logins is a ridiculous process. Overall, this would be a one-star review if it wasn't so much fun to play as a family or with others online.  Other reviews are accurate. These controllers, accessories, and other garbage required to play are delicate and expensive.
variant: Style: Console Color: Neon Blue and Red
author: SwampdonkeY
product: Nintendo Switch with Gray Joy‑Con - HAC-001(-01)
Split_1: The switch is a fun system when it works.
Split_2: 3 months in this piece of delicate plastic stopped "switching."
Split_3: The console works when plugged into the dock and displays on the TV but not when removed from the dock.
Split_4: When removed from the dock the screen is black but sound can be heard.

title: These gaming consoles are ridiculous these days.
content: Why on earth would you want or need Plugable Ethernet Adapters: USB 2.0 vs. USB 3.0 vs. USB-C when Nintendo only supports USB 2.0 in the first place? This is freaking stupid! The Nintendo Switch it's self is wireless lol meaning it supports WI-FI. The additional remotes that you can buy aka controllers are so cheaply made and the dock is also made from cheap plastic parts. You drop this thing once and trust me it's gonna break into a million pieces. The games are so over priced and they are literally installed on some sort of SD card...., Really!? The memory is stored on an additional microSD and microSDXC cards, and has 32GB of internal NAND memory. So be prepared to buy more memory. The HDMI cable the console comes with is literally a cheap $3 dollar cable you can buy at Walmart lol. Where is Mike Tyson's Punch out in 3D new and improved? Why is this console NOT backwards compatible? Why have an internal USB 3.0 port but only supports 2.0? Are you freaking kidding me!? No software updates? No additional upgrades? Mario Galaxy 1 and 2 should of been on the same game! Super Mario 64 should of been in widescreen HD! We should be able to play all our old Mario, Zelda and punch-out games on this console in 3D renewed!~ Yes the only games worth playing are the Mario Franchised ones and of course Zelda's breath of the wild. Nintendo has officially ripped people off during a national pandemic. We thought you wanted our business ....
variant: Style: Console Color: Neon Blue and Red
author: spider-man
product: Nintendo Switch with Gray Joy‑Con - HAC-001(-01)
Split_1: Why on earth would you want or need Plugable Ethernet Adapters: USB 2.0 vs. USB 3.0 vs. USB-C when Nintendo only supports USB 2.0 in the first place?
Split_3: The Nintendo Switch it's self is wireless lol meaning it supports WI-FI.
Split_4: The additional remotes that you can buy aka controllers are so cheaply made and the dock is also made from cheap plastic parts.

title: nostalgic with a modern twist
content: I bought this for my kids and they seem to enjoy it - i do like that you can play it in a portable mode and connect to a large screen tv.  The controller is rather small when splitting it to do two player so people with large hands will find it hard to use.  The orientation of the controller and how it's held varies per game and screen so that can be confusing.  Having the loop at the top of the controller on one side and on the bottom of the other, can assist with a left handed player but for right handers it can feel odd.  My biggest gripe is the motion sensors on them aren't as accurate or sensitive as a Wii controller.  But overall thus far is a fun setup.
variant: Style: Console Color: Mario Red & Blue Edition
author: Nam N.
product: Nintendo Switch with Gray Joy‑Con - HAC-001(-01)

Split_4: Having the loop at the top of the controller on one side and on the bottom of the other, can assist with a left handed player but for right handers it can feel odd.

title: VERY high-demand, limited edition. Worth it
content: The console is adorable and the battery life/display seemed a little better to me compared to my original switch. Vibrant and cute joy-cons. Very hard to find because Best Buy and Wal-Mart ran out and would not post more in stock. They said they couldn't pre-order/seemed unwilling to help before it was released months ago when I asked, and all had in-store pickup in locations hundreds of miles away when it finally came out. I was told they only make these and the replacement controllers in Japan when I asked about a pair at Gamestop. Don't know how true that is but it seems it. I still go easy on the cons to this day because of my fear of drift and damage

title: Nintendo's best console in a long time
content: Sure, it's no PS4 or PS5, but it's an incredible little machine with such incredible versatility in such a tiny package. While it might not have the pure processing power and graphics capability of the other two major systems it does do what Nintendo has done best for a long time, provide a reasonably priced quality portable gaming system. The advantage this time is that the Switch is both a home console and a portable console in one unit. This is something that consoles in general have never really been able to do until now and it's amazing how great the game quality is even in this small form factor. I mean, the Wii was good in the motion control but the gimmick did wear after a bit. The WiiU really felt like a disappointment in that it just didn't bring much to the table and Nintendo clearly wasn't going to be able to compete in the home console market against the other two juggernauts. What Nintendo has always been great at though is dominating the portable gaming market and the switch sees them bringing their expertise in the portable market to the home console market in a power play that really paid off in my opinion. Now, this system does still suffer from some of Nintendo's generally less favorable business practices so do take that in to account. The price for the Switch itself actually isn't that unreasonable so I don't fault them for that whatsoever. The peripherals, on the other hand, really put a dent in the pocketbook if you need to buy anything that didn't come in the box (and you probably will need to at some point, let's be honest). The price of games also comes at a premium just as it has with past Nintendo systems as you will rarely see even older games every discounted or put on sale while such things are very common with the the competing systems. For instances, "Zelda: Link's Awakening", which has roughly 13 to 15 hours of content, will still cost you $60 which is incredibly high for a game that offers so little content with little replay value. Sadly Nintendo has a tendency of doing this and always has so do be prepared to pay premium prices for most games with the Switch. All in all I still think the unit is worth it particularly since you just can't find a better portable gaming platform than this. I definitely recommend getting the Switch over the Switch Lite as those are fully integrated and if you bust an analog stick or a button you're pretty much screwed. With a Switch you can replace the side controllers as you need and we all know controller buttons and analog sticks can wear over time so that alone is worth it. I mean, for $100 more you get a heck of a lot better of a system than you do with a lite so I highly recommend going this route if you're looking in to a Switch.
variant: Style: Console Color: Neon Blue and Red
author: Keonyn
product: Nintendo Switch with Gray Joy‑Con - HAC-001(-01)
Split_1: Sure, it's no PS4 or PS5, but it's an incredible little machine with such incredible versatility in such a tiny package.
Split_2: While it might not have the pure processing power and graphics capability of the other two major systems it does do what Nintendo has done best for a long time, provide a reasonably priced quality portable gaming system.
Split_3: The advantage this time is that the Switch is both a home console and a portable console in one unit.
Split_4: This is something that consoles in general have never really been able to do until now and it's amazing how great the game quality is even in this small form factor.

title: At this price, not ONE game included ?! - Is this a joke?
content: I received this as a Christmas gift from my brother; an expensive & indulgent one at that, but very thoughtful, nonetheless. Though I am not a 'gamer', I've gone through fits & spurts of playing, but never been interested enough to invest in a consule/etc - my experience the past 20 yrs has been the odd game on my Iphone/Ipad. Today, I finally sat down, ready to see what the hype is over - took everything out of the box, getting set up . . . only to find that there isnt even ONE game included? This was a gift, and I didnt want to know the price, but when I found out I was more than angry with the manufacturer. $300 and no game included? SO very wrong! And looking at the games offered; $50 - $60 bucks a pop? Are you kidding me? No thanks. This will now sit in a box in the closet. Disappointed to say the LEAST.

title: Difficult installation.

This assembly is made of thin plastic so I have to mount it next to the TV; I am afraid that it might break if accidental drop for some reasons. title: First Time Nintendo Switch User
content: As someone who's been playing on the PS4, the Nintendo Switch is a great change of pace. This is my ever handheld gaming device and I got to say, man is it impressive! For starters, the design of the switch is awesome, not too heavy or light. Every time you slip the joycons on the side of the switch, it makes a satisfying click sound. The dock is great for playing games on your TV or monitor (plus it looks clean too). After spending about 10 hours on the switch, I am satisfied with the joycons and feel no need to purchase the pro controller. Although the joycons are a bit small (perfect for kids), they will get the job done. Next, it is important that you take storage into consideration since the switch only comes with a base of 32 gb. I bought the SanDisk 128 gb card and that will be enough for me. If you plan on playing games like Mortal Kombat, I'd suggest upgrading to 200 and above, since those games take up more storage (ex. MK11 Aftermath is 30 gb). Depending on how much you play, battery life will vary. Of course, more labor-intensive games will drain the battery quicker. I only have two games on my switch so far (Attack on Titan and Fortnite) and those games tend to drain the battery significantly faster. I don’t have any other games to compare to, but while playing AoT, the battery lasted about 4-5 hours before needing a charge. This is super impressive since AoT is an open-world style game with dozens of titans running around the map destroying buildings and such, but frames will drop from time to time if there too much going on at once. Even after playing for a long time, the switch is only some-what warm, which is great if you are playing in handheld mode. Lastly, I want to talk about the price point of the switch. The retail price is $299.99 and that's what I paid for when I bought the Mario Version. It's a steep price since it's alongside the price point of an Xbox or PS4, but it is worth it if you enjoy playing games on the go and love Nintendo titles such as Zelda and Mario. In addition to the retail price of the console, also take into account other expenses such as extra storage (I would only buy the ones from Nintendo, SanDisk, or Samsung), a screen protector (very important in my opinion. The first thing I did when I unboxed the switch was to put on a screen protector), extra controllers and/or joycons, and maybe Nintendo's online membership if you want to play online and with friends (games like Fortnite will not need a membership). All in all, the switch is a great device and I can't recommend it enough. It's a great console for families or if you just want to play alone.
variant: Style: Console Color: Mario Red & Blue Edition
author: Chao C.
product: Nintendo Switch with Gray Joy‑Con - HAC-001(-01)
Split_1: As someone who's been playing on the PS4, the Nintendo Switch is a great change of pace.
Split_2: This is my ever handheld gaming device and I got to say, man is it impressive!
Split_3: For starters, the design of the switch is awesome, not too heavy or light.
Split_4: Every time you slip the joycons on the side of the switch, it makes a satisfying click sound.

title: An Amazing Little Console
content: The Nintendo Switch is a great gaming console for people new to gaming and veterans alike. Offering an extensive library of games for both kids and adults, it’s a device the whole family can enjoy. It’s substantially more affordable than its competitors Microsoft’s Xbox One, and Sony’s PlayStation 4. Produced by the well-known gaming giant Nintendo, a company with over 131 years of gaming entertainment under its belt, consumers can rest assured that they are making a quality purchase. The Switch is a hybrid gaming console released by Nintendo on March 3rd, 2017. Since its debut, it has received a significant hardware upgrade in addition to limited editions of the console. On September 20th, 2019, the Switch Lite was released nationwide. This version of the console lacks the hybrid functionality, giving up the ability to connect to a TV in favor of a lower price and a smaller, lighter form factor. The standard console is available at most retailers and online for $299 and the Lite for $199, though COVID 19 has seen these prices climb substantially higher. For this review, I will be focusing on the standard upgraded edition of the platform. The main appeal of a hybrid console is that it can be used in two configurations: handheld mode for portable play, or placed into its dock allowing the device to stream to a TV. The small controllers, called Joy-Cons, slide into slots on the sides when in handheld mode. They can also be removed and used as two separate controllers, saving parents $80 on a second controller for multiplayer situations when docked. The new revision includes a more power-efficient CPU, the brain of the console, and a brighter, more vibrant screen. Upgrading the CPU has led to a 30 percent increase in efficiency, meaning more gaming time when away from a power source. The old battery is reported to last 2.5-6.5 hours and the new one 4.5 to 9 hours, depending on the game and how high the brightness of the screen is set. In terms of software, the Switch offers an extensive library, a must for any gaming console. Without ample software to support the platform, the audience may quickly run out of games to play or things to do; this is not the case with the Switch. The library of games available for purchase can be accessed through the built-in eShop. These games can be downloaded to an SD card inserted into the system. Games can also be purchased physically in a cartridge format for those who would prefer the longevity of owning their library physically. The collection of games offered is vast and ranges from family-friendly titles such as Mario, Zelda, and Donkey Kong; to more adult titles such as Doom, Skyrim, and Wolfenstein: The New Colossus. The support for this system is incredible, primarily due to the fact that the install base is so large. The surge in sales has given incentive to developers and publishers to create more content, something which cannot be said about the previous Nintendo console, the Nintendo Wii U. Even after being on the market for more than three years, the substantial library of games shows no sign of this growth slowing down. At purchase straight out of the box, you get: The main console, two Joy-Cons, the Joy-Con grip accessory, two wrist straps for the controllers, the dock, an AC power adapter, and an HDMI cable. SD cards, games, and Nintendo Online must be purchased separately. Consumers wishing to use the online services can buy a membership for $3.99 a month, $7.99 for three months, or $19.99 for a year. A family plan is also offered at $34.99 a year and covers up to eight consoles. Members gain access to exclusive game titles, Super Mario Brothers 35 and Tetris 99. Membership also includes over seventy NES and Super NES titles. Additionally, Nintendo will allow players to back up thei game saves to the cloud, easing fears of ever losing game progress. What is lacking, however, is any real social aspect to the online community. Without voice chat, a means to message your friends, or in-game achievements, the platform falls short, in this regard, compared to its competitors. Customers have voiced complaints on this matter for years, only to be ignored. Another negative to be aware of is the issue of Joy-Con drift. Over time the thumbsticks are known to wear out, and games will register input when there is no action being performed by the player. Nintendo has vehemently fought against claims that this is an issue, even to the point of being taken to court by many parties in the form of class-action lawsuits. Drift is a reasonably widespread phenomenon and cannot be overstated; the likelihood that you will experience issues with the longevity of your Joy-Cons is high. This may or may not be a concern, as Nintendo offers to replace controllers that experience this. If you have issues with faulty controllers, you’ll likely need to purchase additional ones. The controllers can be bought separately from the console for $80 for use until Nintendo gets around to repairing the ones you already own. In conclusion, I still highly recommend this system despite its shortcomings. The hours I have spent enjoying a vast collection of exciting, engaging titles on it have far outweighed any frustration I have experienced with the controllers' durability or the lackluster online experience. The ability to take your game from the living room to on the go and back again is a real treat. If you’re a busy person looking for an affordable console, this is sure to meet your needs.
variant: Style: Console Color: Neon Blue and Red
author: Rachel Gullion
product: Nintendo Switch with Gray Joy‑Con - HAC-001(-01)
Split_1: The Nintendo Switch is a great gaming console for people new to gaming and veterans alike.
Split_2: Offering an extensive library of games for both kids and adults, it’s a device the whole family can enjoy.
Split_3: It’s substantially more affordable than its competitors Microsoft’s Xbox One, and Sony’s PlayStation 4.
Split_4: Produced by the well-known gaming giant Nintendo, a company with over 131 years of gaming entertainment under its belt, consumers can rest assured that they are making a quality purchase.

title: No regrets. I waited and snapped it up when it was in stock again at retail price.
content: Finally got my hands on one at the retail price last month (To hell with price gougers.  I don't ever support them. I hope they die of Covid) and I am having a lot of fun with it. I'm usually a pc gamer but I really like that this is portable too. The battery life is nice and the motion controls are alright but I tend not to use them.  I was confused about where to put my micro sd card till I looked it up. It's hidden under the kickstand which is kind of flimsy and the only real con when compared to the list of pros. So far I've got Skyrim, Lego Harry Potter, My Time at Portia, Nine Parchments, and the Deponia games to occupy me for now. I've wanted one of these for a long time and I do not regret my purchase.
